 And again you are absolutely wrong, both in practical and historical terms. If Jesus was truly guilty of breaking Roman Law and was deserving of crucifixion, which was a Roman method of execution, then either Herod or Pilate would have willingly sentenced Him to death. But Pilate rejected the case and sent Him to his superior, King Herod. And after reviewing the case, he sent Jesus back to Pilate who then offered the Jewish people a choice. To execute Barabbas or Jesus and they chose to crucify Jesus, the innocent one.
 
 Because the Romans wanted to avoid a revolt Pilate agreed to their demands, but not before making the statement which has survived for 2000 years and become a part of the lexicon of cliche's; "Let His blood be on your hands, I wash my hands of this mans fate."
 
 Matthew 27:19 While he was sitting on the judgment seat, his wife sent him a message, saying, "Have nothing to do with that righteous Man; for last night I suffered greatly in a dream because of Him." 20 But the chief priests and the elders persuaded the crowds to ask for Barabbas and to put Jesus to death. 21 But the governor said to them, "Which of the two do you want me to release for you?" And they said, "Barabbas." 22 Pilate said to them, "Then what shall I do with Jesus who is called Christ?" They all said, "Crucify Him!" 23 And he said, "Why, what evil has He done?" But they kept shouting all the more, saying, "Crucify Him!" 
 24 When Pilate saw that he was accomplishing nothing, but rather that a riot was starting, he took water and washed his hands in front of the crowd, saying, "I am innocent of this Man's blood; see to that yourselves." 25 And all the people said, "His blood shall be on us and on our children!" 26 Then he released Barabbas for them; but after having Jesus scourged, he handed Him over to be crucified.
 So according to the Roman authorities involved in judging Jesus, He had done nothing worthy of death at all. He gave the mob what they wanted for political expediency. Much like the political party you support today would do if they were in a similar political situation. emoticon_rolleyes

The Romans were bastards and not lenient with trouble makers and secular historical documentation describes Pilate as brute who hated the Jews. Also, Herod was a Jew - he did not have the power to execute anyone. And are you saying that Herod was Pilot's or Jesus' superior (seriously not clear)? There is no way that a foreigner, even a foreign king, would out-rank the Roman representative in the area.
 
 Please understand me here, Archangel. I find this interesting from a historical point of view ONLY and the Bible, although an impotant historical document, is not the only one and is not a history book.
 
 If you are intested in discussing the history that is fine. If you are going to preach or tell me I am sou-less or some such thing - never mind.
